awd_titl_txt: Identification of Cloud-Nucleating and Ice-Nucleating Biological Aerosol Sources
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on laboratory experiments to provide the quantitative data needed to understand and predict the impacts of marine emissions on cloud formation in the atmosphere. The primary objectives of this effort are: (1) Determine which phytoplankton groups are the most effective producers of aerosols; (2) Determine when in the bloom cycle of the phytoplankton the organisms are the most effective in producing aerosol; and (3) For the most effective aerosol producers, identify the specific components of the aerosol that are responsible for activating cloud formation.

This project will provide fundamental information on the linkages between marine ecosystem structure and function and cloud formation in the atmosphere.  Representative phytoplankton groups, including cyanobacteria, diatoms, and coccolithophores, will be grown in a large mesocosm tank Phytoplankton growth will be followed closely by measuring changes in the concentrations of chlorophyll. Aerosols will be generated from the surface water of the mesocosm to identify which organisms serve as the most effective generators of aerosol, cloud condensation nuclei (CCN), and ice nuclei (IN). A suite of biological and chemical techniques will be used to characterize the cloud-nucleating and ice-nucleating properties of the aerosol.

This project will provide insight for field measurements in the real ocean. The researchers will perform additional CCN fractionation experiments during a different project that involves four cruises in the North Atlantic to take place in 2015-2020. Hence, the fractionation experiments conduct through this research will provide a direct comparison to field measurements.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout this project, emissions produced from phytoplankton monocultures were conducted in month long mesocosm experiments in the laboratory.  For the initial mesocosm experiments, organisms from three representative (and very different) phytoplankton groups, cyanobacteria, diatoms, and coccolithophores, specifically, Synechoccocus sp., Thalassiosira weissflogii, and Emiliania huxleyi, were studied. Additionally, Emiliania huxleyi mesocosm runs were conducted in an unperturbed state, as for the cyanobacteria and diatom mesocosm runs, and also under conditions deliberately spiked with a virus known to infect Emiliania huxleyi.

 

Measurements over the mesocosms were be used to identify which organisms serve as the most effective generators of aerosol, warm cloud droplets and atmospheric ice crystals. A suite of supporting biological and chemical techniques were used to characterize the aerosols and source waters. Samples were collected daily so that emissions of cloud-nucleating and ice-nucleating aerosols could be measured during each characteristic stage of growth cycle. Microorganisms of all tested types were most ice-active in the initial growth stage.

 

Although cyanobacteria, diatoms, and coccolithophores are all photosynthetic marine plankton, there are large differences in their physiology. The largest differences arise from the fact that cyanobacteria are prokaryotic and lack much of the internal organization found in the eukaryotic diatoms and coccolithophores. As well, they differ in size and composition of their cell wall. However, they have similar metabolisms and growth patterns, utilizing many of the same major nutrients. Despite all the differences in physiology between the three species studied, the warmest freezing temperatures and the most INP were present during the exponential growth phase of the experiments.

 

This key finding of this project, that marine organisms most effectively produce ice-nucleating particles during the exponential growth phase of the life cycle, was also observed in the field during NAAMES 2. This finding contrasts earlier work suggesting that the death phase was a more productive time for aerosol and ice-nucleating emissions. This is a step forward in our understanding of the drivers of global marine ice nucleation.

 

On this project, a wide range of marine aerosol samples was surveyed for their ice nucleation activity. These include laboratory measurements above monocultures, primary aerosol samples collected over the North Atlantic Ocean, isolated Synechococcus, photosynthetic picoeukaryotes, and photosynthetic nanoeukaryotes samples collected from North Atlantic surface waters, and marine phytoplankton viruses. All of these sources of marine aerosol exhibited moderately effective abilities to catalyze ice nucleation in atmospheric droplets. However, Emiliana huxleyi was only an effective ice nucleation under rapid cell division conditions. In conclusions, marine aerosols represent a diverse and significant source of catalysts for ice nucleation. By comparison, marine aerosol has very little impact on the warm cloud droplet formation. Outreach activities include a story about our project, narrated by graduate student, Jessica Mirrielees, which has aired on the location radio station, and a short video, and a series of podcasts on related topics. In addition to graduate students, 6 undergraduates were introduced to interdisciplinary laboratory work during this project, and two of them presented their results at national conferences. Two students earned graduate degrees (Elise Wilbourn, Ph.D.; Brianna Hendrickson, M.S.) based on their contributions to the research.
